proof:
Proof. The main part of the proof is to show that for any configuration $F \in \mathcal{B}$ it holds that
$$
c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| \le -\rho n \text{ with } \rho = \eta/20.
\quad(10)
$$
Let us conclude the proof of the lemma assuming (10) for the moment. We first show that (10) translates into $w_C(F)/Z_C \le q^{-\rho n}$ for all $\beta > 0$. Indeed, if $e^\beta - 1 \le q^{2/d}$, we will use the lower bound $Z_C \ge q^{n_c} \ge q^{n(1-e^{-d/3})}$, where the second inequality holds whp. Thus, for any $F \in \mathcal{B}$,
$$
\frac{w_C(F)}{Z_C} = q^{c(F)-n+ne^{-d/3}} (e^\beta - 1)^{|E_C|-|E_C \setminus F|} \le q^{c(F)-\frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| - n + \frac{2}{d}|E_C| + ne^{-d/3}}.
$$
Using that whp $|E_C| \le |E_G| \le nd/2 + \frac{\eta n}{10}$, we have that $\frac{2}{d}|E_C| - n \le n-n+\frac{\eta n}{10}$. Hence, for all $d$ sufficiently large (recall that $\eta$ is an absolute constant independent of $d$), we obtain that $w_C(F)/Z_C \le q^{-\rho n/4}$. Analogously, if $e^\beta - 1 \ge q^{2/d}$, we use the lower bound $Z_C \ge (e^\beta-1)^{|E_C|}$ so that for any $F \in \mathcal{B}$
$$
\frac{w_C(F)}{Z_C} = q^{c(F)} (e^\beta - 1)^{-|E_C \setminus F|} \le q^{c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F|} \le q^{-\rho n}.
$$
To finish, note that the size of $\mathcal{B}$ is trivially at most $|\Omega_C| \le 2^{|E_C|} \le 2^{nd/2+n\eta/40}$. Thus we get
$$
\frac{1}{Z_C} \sum_{F \in \mathcal{B}} w_C(F) \le 2^{nd/2+n\eta/40} q^{-\rho n/4}
$$
which is $\le e^{-n}$ for all $q$ large enough.

We next return to the proof of (10). Fix an arbitrary $F \in \mathcal{B}$. We partition the vertices of C into sets $S_1, S_2, S_3, S_4$ depending on the size of their components in $(V_C, F)$. Namely, we set $S_1$ to be the set of vertices in singleton components, $S_2$ the set of vertices in components of size between 2 and $\log n$, $S_3$ the set of vertices in components of size $ > \log n$ and $\le \frac{n}{\ell}$, and $S_4$ the set of vertices in components of size $> \frac{n}{\ell}$. For $i=1,\ldots,4$, let $n_i := |S_i|$. We have then the trivial upper bound
$$
c(F) \le n_1 + \frac{n_2}{2} + \frac{n_3}{\log n} + 6.
\quad(11)
$$
Next we give a lower bound on $|E_C\setminus F|$ by analysing how many out-edges are incident to vertices in $S_1, S_2, S_3, S_4$.
1. Consider first components of size 1. Every edge adjacent to any $v \in S_1$ must be in $E_C \setminus F$. Thus, aggregating over $v \in S_1$, we have at least $\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{deg}_G(S_1)$ edges in $E_C \setminus F$ adjacent to vertices in $S_1$; note that the $\frac{1}{2}$-factor accounts for potential double-counting (edges that join two vertices in $S_1$).
2. Let $k$ be a constant such that whp all sets of size $\le \log n$ are $k$-treelike (Lemma 29). Also by Lemma 30 whp any connected set of size $\le 2k$ is 1-treelike.
Consider now any component $\kappa$ whose size is between 2 and $\log n$. If $\kappa$ has size $< 2k$, then it is 1-treelike, so $e_G(\kappa) \le |V_G(\kappa)|$. This gives
$$
|E_G(V_G(\kappa), \overline{V_G(\kappa)})| \ge \mathrm{deg}_G(\kappa) - 2|V_G(\kappa)|.
$$
If $\kappa$ has size between $2k$ and $\log n$, the it is $k$-treelike, so $e_G(\kappa) \le k+|V_G(\kappa)| \le \frac{3}{2}|V_G(\kappa)|$, yielding that
$$
|E_G(V_G(\kappa), \overline{V_G(\kappa)})| \ge \mathrm{deg}_G(\kappa) - 3|V_G(\kappa)|.
$$
Aggregating over all components $\kappa$ in $S_2$, we therefore obtain at least $\frac{1}{2}(\mathrm{deg}_G(S_2) - 3n_2)$ edges in $E_C \setminus F$ that are adjacent to vertices in $S_2$. (Once again, the factor $\frac{1}{2}$ accounts for double-counting).
3. Consider next components with size between $\log n$ and $\frac{n}{\ell}$. By Proposition 11 and taking $d$ large enough (namely, $d > A$ where A is the absolute constant there in), we have that whp every connected subset $S$ in $G$ with size $\log n \le |S| \le \frac{n}{\ell}$ satisfies $|E_G(S,\bar{S})| \ge \frac{3}{5}|\mathrm{deg}_G(S)|$. Therefore, for any component $\kappa$ of $(V_C, F)$ in this size range, we have at least $\frac{3}{5}|\mathrm{deg}_G(\kappa)|$ edges going out of it, and therefore belong to $E_C \setminus F$. Aggregating over $\kappa$ (and accounting once again for potential double-counting), we obtain that the total number of out-edges adjacent to vertices in $S_3$ is at least $\frac{3}{10}\mathrm{deg}_G(S_3)$.
4. Finally consider components with size $> \frac{n}{\ell}$. If $\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le n(1-\eta/4)$, we get from the second part of Lemma 33 that for all $d$ large enough $|E_G(S_4, \bar{S}_4)| \ge \frac{d}{4d|S_4|(n-|S_4|)} > \frac{dn}{30}\eta$ (since $\eta/4 \le \frac{5\eta}{6}$). Therefore, the total number of out-edges adjacent to vertices in $S_4$ is at least $\frac{dn}{30}\eta \mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n - \eta n/4)\}$. (Note that if $|S_4|$ is outside the range $\eta n/4$ and $n(1-\eta/4)$ we use the trivial lower bound 0.)

Combining the above, we conclude that
$$
|E_C \setminus F| \ge \frac{1}{2}[\mathrm{deg}_G(S_1 \cup S_2) - 3n_2 + \frac{3}{5}\mathrm{deg}_G(S_3) + \frac{dn}{15}\eta \mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (1 - \eta n/4)\}]
$$
$$
\ge \frac{1}{2}[(1-d^{-1/3})d(n_1+n_2+\frac{3}{5}n_3-2ne^{-d^{1/3}}) + \frac{dn}{15}\eta \mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (1 - \eta n/4)\}],
\quad(12)
$$
where the second inequality follows from the fact that the number of vertices of $G$ which have degree $<(1-d^{-1/3})d$ is less than $2ne^{-d^{1/3}}$ (Proposition 41). From (11) and (12), we therefore have that
$$
c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| \le n_1 + (\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{3})n_2 + \frac{n_3}{\log n} + 6 - (1-d^{-1/3})[n_1+n_2+\frac{3}{5}n_3]
$$
$$
+ 2ne^{-d^{1/3}} - \frac{\eta n}{15} \mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n - \eta n/4)\}.
$$
For $d$ and $n$ sufficiently large, we have that $\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}-d^{-1/3} \ge \frac{1}{4}$ and $\frac{1}{\log n} - \frac{3d^{-1/3}}{4} \ge \frac{1}{4}$, so
$$
c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n_1 - \frac{n_2+n_3}{4} - \frac{\eta n}{6}\mathbf{1}\{\eta n/4 \le |S_4| \le (n-\eta n/4)\} + 2ne^{-d^{1/3}} + 6.
\quad(13)
$$
Now we split the analysis into four cases. We will use that whp $|E_C| \ge |E_K| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3} > \frac{dn}{25}$ for all $d$ large enough (Lemma 39) and also that whp $|E_C| \le |E_G| \le \frac{dn}{2} + \frac{\eta n}{40}$.
*   Case 0: $n_1 \ge 1-\frac{2\eta}{3}$. Here we show that $|F| < \frac{\eta}{10}|E_C|$, contradicting our assumption on $|F|$ coming from $F \in \mathcal{B}$ (and hence we can rule out this case). Indeed, no edge incident to a vertex in $S_1$ is in $F$, so $|E_C \setminus F| \ge \frac{1}{2}\mathrm{deg}_G(S_1) \ge \frac{1}{2}d(1-d^{-1/3})(n_1 - 2ne^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}})$ where the last inequality follows from the fact that $G$ has at most $2ne^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}}$ vertices with degree $< (1-d^{-1/3})d$ (Proposition 41). Hence
    $$
    |F| = |E_C| - |E_C \setminus F| \le \frac{dn}{2} + \frac{\eta n}{40} - \frac{dn}{2}[(1-\frac{2\eta}{3})(1-d^{-1/3}) - 2e^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}}].
    $$
    For all $d$ large enough, $\frac{\eta}{40}+\frac{2\eta}{3}+d^{-1/3}+2e^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}} \le \frac{5\eta}{6}$, thus also $|F| \le \frac{dn}{2} \cdot \frac{5\eta}{6}$. But $|E_C| \ge \frac{dn}{27}\frac{9}{2}$, which gives $|F| < \frac{\eta}{10}|E_C|$, contradicting $F \in \mathcal{B}$.
*   Case 1: $n_4 > n(1-\eta/2)$. Since we have at most 6 components with size $> n/6$, in this case it follows that $c(F) < n-n(1-\eta/2)+6 = \eta n/2+6$. Since $|F| \le (1-\frac{9\eta}{10})|E_C|$ we have $|E_C \setminus F| \ge \frac{9\eta}{10}|E_C| > \frac{dn}{27}\eta$, so for $n$ large enough
    $$
    c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| < 6+\frac{\eta n}{2} - \frac{\eta n}{12} = 6 - \frac{5}{12}\eta n \le -\frac{\eta n}{20}.
    $$
*   Case 2: $n_2+n_3 \ge \eta n/3$. Plugging this into (13) (using the trivial bound $n_1 < n$ and ignoring the indicator), we obtain that
    $$
    c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n - \frac{\eta n}{12} + 2e^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}} + 6
    $$
    Since $\eta$ does not depend on $d$, for all $d$ (and $n$) large enough, $d^{-1/3}+2e^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}}+6/n \le \eta/30$, and so for all $n$ large enough, yielding once again (10).
*   Case 3: $n_2+n_3 < \eta n/3$, $n_1 < n(1-2\eta/3)$, and $n_4 < n(1-\eta/2)$. Since $n_1+n_2+n_3+n_4 = |V_C|$, we have that $n_4 \ge n_c-n_1-n_2-n_3 \ge n-ne^{-d/3}-\frac{\eta n}{3}-\frac{2\eta n}{3}+\frac{2\eta n}{3}$ which is at least $\eta n/4$ for all $d$ large enough. In this case, (13) gives for $d$ and $n$ large that
    $$
    c(F) - \frac{2}{d}|E_C \setminus F| \le d^{-1/3}n - \frac{\eta n}{6} + 2e^{-\frac{1}{2}d^{1/3}} + 6 \le -\eta n/20.
    $$
This finishes the proof of (10) and completes the proof of Lemma 53.
